text_description: Arturo Luz receives the first Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
The works of Luna and Hidalgo are exhibited in Oro Plata at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila.
Jose Joya receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
Federico Alcuaz receives the National Artist award.
The Bau-Malay tradition or geometric pottery of south China is found in coastal sites in Mindanao, Bohol, northern Palawan, and the Calamianes Island; it is dated to the 10th century.

media_caption: Soterania Puson y Quintos de Ventenilla, Dionisio de Castro, 1892
text_headline: Soterania Puson Y Quintos De Ventenilla, 1892, by Dionisio de Castro is an example of 19th century portraiture called miniaturismo
text_description: Soterania Puson Y Quintos De Ventenilla, 1892, by Dionisio de Castro is an example of 19th century portraiture called miniaturismo, featuring the sitter wearing her jewelry and accoutrements.

media_caption: Balanghai CE 320, cabo negro, Ambangan, Libertad, Butuan, Agusan del Norte Province, northeastern Mindanao
media_credit: (Photo by Roezielle Joy Iglesia)
text_headline: Balanghai boat
text_description: Balanghai boats, dated 320 CE, are used for trade, as seen in archaeological excavation in Butuan, Agusan del Norte.
The style of impressionism is used by Juan Luna (1857-1899) for The Parisian Life, 1892, a depiction of a lady sitting inside a café in Paris.
Bencab receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
Tony Velasquez receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
The first Philippine Artists Awards (PAA) is held; it will later be supported by Philip Morris.
Malang Santos receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
Arturo Luz receives the National Artist award.
The Conservative vs. Modernist debate between Edades and Tolentino is rekindled in magazines published in July 1948.
Pottery with red slips which are painted, impressed, incised, excised, and appliqued, are used in central Philippines, Cagayan Valley, and Palawan.

media_caption: Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay and Francisco Suarez, Murillo Velarde Map of 1734, CARTA HYDROGRAPHICA Y CHOROGRAPHICA DE LAS YSLAS FILIPINAS
media_credit: Geography and Map Division, Library of Congress Collection
text_description: Carta hydrographica y chorographica de las Yslas Filipinas, drawn by Fr Pedro Murillo Velarde, is printed, using four copper plates. Nicolas Dela Cruz Bagay and Francisco Suarez use the technique of copper engraving for the Map of 1734 and 1744 and their marginal vignettes.
The AAP sponsors the First Neo-Realist exhibition as support for modern art.
J. Elizalde Navarro receives the National Artist award.
President Quezon elevates the barong tagalog as the national male costume, with he himself wearing it as President of the new Commonwealth of the Philippines.
Jewelry consisting of two shell discs and a perforated disc made from a cone shell are used, as evidenced by findings in Duyong Cave, Palawan (2680 BCE).
The Atelier of Modern Art is founded under Victorio C. Edades, Diosdado M. Lorenzo (1906-1984), and Galo B. Ocampo.
Paintings by Filipino Artists, featuring the art collection of Jorge B. Vargas, is published.

media_caption: Ang Kiukok, Crucifixion, 1968
text_description: Ang Kiukok receives the National Artist award.
Art in the Philippines by Dominador Castañeda is published.
Jaime Laya publishes Letras y Figuras.

media_caption: National Artist Abdulmari Imao in an episode of Art Republik, 2012
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of NCCA)
text_description: Cesar Legaspi and Abdulmari Asia Imao receive the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.

media_caption: Norberto Roldan, The Matriarch and The Wedding in Negros (diptych), 1989
media_credit: National Gallery Singapore Collection (Photo from the artist)
text_description: The Green Papaya Art Projects is founded by Norberto Roldan, Donna Miranda, Manny Chaves, and curator Bobi Valenzuela, as a project space envisioning experimentation in art in a non-commercial venture.
Paete sculptor Mariano Madrinan (1858-1939) wins critical acclaim in the Amsterdam Universal Exposition, by garnering the first prize for his Mater Dolorosa.

media_caption: National Artist Abdulmari Imao in an episode of Art Republik, 2012
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of NCCA)
text_description: Bencab and Abdulmari Asia Imao receive the National Artist award.

media_caption: Roberto Feleo, Tau-tao
media_credit: (Photo from Galeri Nasional Indonesia)
text_description: Roberto Feleo (b. 1954) creates the installation work Tau-tau, using the traditional pinalakpak process in creating figures based on Bagobo mythology.

media_caption: Green nephrite lingling-o and double animal-headed ear pendants from the Tabon Caves in Palawan
text_headline: Jade Ling-ling-o, an ornament made from Fengtian jade from Taiwan, comes to Batanes. Early Filipinos developed a style of jade carving, exemplified by the ling-ling-o found in Uyaw Cave, Palawan (ca 500-300 BCE).
text_description: Jade Ling-ling-o, an ornament made from Fengtian jade from Taiwan, comes to Batanes. Early Filipinos developed a style of jade carving, exemplified by the ling-ling-o found in Uyaw Cave, Palawan (ca 500-300 BCE).
A photograph of the celebration of the Republic of Malolos features a singkaban triumphal arch.

Un Indio Modelo is painted by Telesforo Sucgang (1855-1916), an anatomical study of a semi-nude brown-skinned male, posed inside a studio. It may also be considered as the continuity of the tipos del pais style of painting, employing academic principles of painting.

media_caption: Judy Freya Sibayan, Scapular Gallery
media_credit: (Photo from the artist)
text_description: Judy Freya Sibayan (b. 1953) starts the performance Scapular Gallery Nomad (1997 – 2002), a concept-based work performed anywhere and anytime, as a project of institutional critique.
Azulejos or tiles, ivory carvings, and capiz are exported to Mexico.
Jose Joya receives the National Artist award.

media_caption: UGATLahi Artist Collective, Erapzilla
media_credit: (Photo from the artist collective)
text_description: The effigy Erapzilla by UGATLahi is used in a protest rally and the Welgang Bayan organized by the Erap Resign Movement and Bagong Alyansang Makabayan.

media_caption: Kublai Ponce Millan, The Durian
media_credit: (Photo from the artist)
text_description: Kublai Milan creates The Durian, a monumental sculpture done in concrete, for the Davao International Airport.

media_caption: Tad Ermitaño, Robot Gamelan Quartet
media_credit: (Photo by Joel Ong)
text_description: Robot Gamelan Quartet by Tad Ermitaño (b. 1964) is included in the exhibition of the 2008 International Symposium on Electronic Art (ISEAS2008) and exhibited in the National Museum of Singapore.

media_caption: Louie Cordero, Nardong Tae, Issue No 1
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of the artist and ARNDT Fine Art)
text_description: Nardong Tae by Louie Cordero is included in the exhibition The Philippine Contemporary: To Scale the Past and the Possible at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila.

media_caption: Black Nazarene of Quiapo, Early 1600s
media_credit: (Photo from Quiapo Church Social Communications Department)
text_description: The image of the Black Nazarene, aka Poong Itim na Nazareno, which was crafted in Mexico, is brought to the Philippines by the Augustinian Recollects through the galleon.

media_caption: Main retablo and altar of Silang church, Silang Retablos, 1671, Nuestra Señora de Candelaria Church
media_credit: (Photo from Fr Marty Dimaranan and Phillip Medina, Silang Parish Council for Culture and Heritage)
text_description: The Silang retablo features elements from Spanish, Mexican, Asian and native artistic traditions; it features the plateresque style of carving and the use of Solomonic columns.

media_caption: Oton Death Mask
text_headline: Oton Death Mask
text_description: Gold ornaments such as jewelry is included in ancient burial customs. Gold sheet is also used as face covers, such as the Oton Death Mask, dated late 15th century, and found in 1973.

media_caption: Maitum Jar No. 21
text_description: Maitum pottery, dated 5 BCE to CE 225 and AD 70 to 370, a period straddling the Philippine Late Neolithic and Early Metal Age, is used as anthropomorphic secondary burial jars. These are discovered in 1992-95, in Sarangani Province in Mindanao.

media_caption: Lorenzo Atlas, Nuestra Señora del Rosario
text_description: Copper engraving is widely used in the 18th century to illustrate religious books, novenas, and lives of saints; engravers identify themselves as “indio tagalo.”

media_caption: A page of illustrations from the Elementos de Perspectiva
media_credit: (Photo from Miguel de Benavides Library, University of Santo Tomas)
text_description: Elementos de Perspectiva, a manual of drawing and painting written in Spanish, is published in the Philippines. It influences painters on how to draw still life, render anatomy, and use perspective.

media_caption: Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, Per Pacem et Libertatem, study
text_description: Per Pacem et Libertatem by Hidalgo is installed in a government building in Manila by December 1907. It is destroyed in 1945.

media_caption: Rizal Monument, Richard Kissling, 1913
media_credit: (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)
text_description: The Rizal Monument by Richard Kissling is installed at the Luneta Park in Manila. His design is replicated in reinforced concrete in the public plazas of towns and cities throughout the 1910s to the 1930s.

media_caption: Francisco Coching, El Indio
text_description: El Indio by Francisco Coching (1919-1998), a komiks story featuring a salakot-wearing hero, is published in Pilipino Komiks.

media_caption: Filipinos Ilustres, lithographic print, Jorge Pineda, based on drawing by Guillermo Tolentino, 1911
text_description: Filipinos Ilustres by Guillermo Tolentino (1890-1976), a fictive group portrait of the heroes and martyrs of the revolution, is drawn. This is later translated into a lithograph by Jorge Pineda and printed by Carmelo and Bauermann.

media_caption: Guillermo Tolentino, Oblation
media_credit: (Photo from  Jefferson Villacruz)
text_description: Guillermo Tolentino makes the Oblation, which becomes the symbol of the University of the Philippines.

media_caption: David Medalla, Cloud Canyons No. 2
media_credit: (Photo from University of Washington Department of Architecture)
text_description: David Medalla’s Cloud Canyons No. 2 aka Bubble Machines, a mixed media work which exemplifies avant-garde art, is presented in England.

media_caption: Willie Vicoy, Vietnam War
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Getty Images)
text_description: Vietnam War, a photograph by Willie Vicoy, becomes an iconic image of that war, after its publication in Newsweek Magazine and Time Magazine.

media_caption: Danilo Dalena, Tres-Seis Dejado, from the Jai-alai series
text_description: Danny Dalena starts his Jai Alai series, which he explores until 1990. The ball game with the aspect of betting is used as metaphor for the human condition in time of crisis in the Philippines.

media_caption: Carlos Villa, Ritual
media_credit: (Photo from Tymar Productions)
text_description: Carlos Villa (1936-2013) does performance art in Ritual, exploring issues of race and multi-culturalism among the migrants in America.

media_caption: Kim Komenich, Joel Abong
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of the Bancroft Library,  University of California, Berkeley)
text_description: Joel Abong photograph by Kim Komenich is circulated internationally, drawing attention to the plight of the sugar workers in Negros.

media_caption: Jose Tence Ruiz, Erding Erdrayb at Ang Kanyang Palasyong Agaw-Tanaw
media_credit: (Photo from the artist)
text_description: Erding Erdrayb at ang Kanyang Palasyong Agaw-Tanaw is an assemblage created by Jose Tence Ruiz, inspired by the survivalist way of life of a jeepney driver.
Angono petroglyphs are carved on Rizal cave walls, first reported by Carlos Botong Francisco (1912-1969) in 1965.

media_caption: Tausug habul tiyahian or embroidered textile
media_credit: (Photo from Ukkil: Visual Arts of the Sulu Archipelago by Ligaya Fernando-Amilbangsa. Ateneo de Manila University Press, 2005.)
text_headline: Indigenous art forms such as textile-making, mat weaving, wood carving, and brass casting are nuanced by the Islamic preference for geometric and floral designs.
text_description: Indigenous art forms such as textile-making, mat weaving, wood carving, and brass casting are nuanced by the Islamic preference for geometric and floral designs. Motifs such as the okir, sarimanok, burqa and batik designs are considered as Muslim art which fuses Islamic beliefs, Hindu-Malay cultural traditions, and indigenous world view and beliefs.
The artifacts excavated from the San Diego in 1992 by archaeologists, include pottery and ceramics, jewelry, coins, armaments and other trade goods, all in use in 1600.
Priceless artworks in the museums, churches and homes of Intramuros are destroyed.
Santiago Bose receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
Art of the Philippines 1521-1957, edited by Winfield Scott Smith III, is published.

media_caption: Mandaya dagger with sheath, 19th century, top and barong or knife from Sulu, 19th century, above
media_credit: (Photos from The Metropolitan Museum of Art)
text_headline: Brass casting in the Philippines before the 15th century supposedly begins in Sulu, creating blades such as the parang with excellent craftsmanship.
text_description: Brass casting in the Philippines before the 15th century supposedly begins in Sulu, creating blades such as the parang with excellent craftsmanship.
Stone tools are used for hunting and gathering, as well as to create tools out of bamboo, rattan, and wood.
The Sa-hyunh Kalanay pottery tradition develops in Southern Philippines after 2000 BC.

media_caption: Retrato de la Familia Azcarraga, Juan Arceo/Juan Arzeo, 1827
text_headline: Juan Arceo (ca 1785-1870) completes the Retrato de la familia Azcárraga, one of the earliest secular portraits in the Philippines.
text_description: Juan Arceo (ca 1785-1870) completes the Retrato de la familia Azcárraga, one of the earliest secular portraits in the Philippines.

Legazpi finds the Santo Nino de Cebu in native attire. The veneration of the image through various performative rituals begins. In the future, the belief and rituals about the image are integrated into the production of festivals employing exotic costumes.

media_caption: Our Lady of Prompt Help, NUESTRA SEÑORA DE  PRONTO SOCORRO, 1585
media_credit: (Photos courtesy of Santiago A. Pilar Library)
text_headline: Chinese artisans who were conscripted to paint religious images, such as the Nuestra Señora de Pronto Socorro, 1585, feature Chinese sensibilities in rendering the Virgin Mary’s face and drapery.
text_description: Chinese artisans who were conscripted to paint religious images, such as the Nuestra Señora de Pronto Socorro, 1585, feature Chinese sensibilities in rendering the Virgin Mary’s face and drapery.
The Novaliches pottery tradition flourishes in northwest Palawan and the Calamianes Islands; it is dated from 250 BC to the 4th century.

media_caption: Lipang Kalabaw, 27 July 1907
text_headline: POLITICAL CARTOONS
text_description: With the defeat of Philippine revolutionary forces, political cartoons are used by nationalists to continue fighting for the ideology of freedom. The image of Juan de la Cruz published in Lipang Kalabaw serves as the symbol of the suffering Filipino.

media_caption: Tony Velasquez, Kalibapi Family, comics series in Tribune, 18 Oct 1943
text_headline: JAPANESE-SPONSORED ILLUSTRATIONS
text_description: Liborio "Gat" Gatbonton (1914-1976) and Tony Velasquez create illustrations for the Japanese-sponsored papers. The Kalibapi Family, a cartoon by Velasquez, exemplifies the Japanese policy of extolling Filipino virtues.

media_caption: Dick Baldovino, Botong Francisco, Series No. 21, 1962
text_headline: BOTONG AND COMPANY
text_description: Botong Francisco and other artists paint backdrops for stage plays and billboard ads.

media_caption: H.R. Ocampo, Genesis, 1969
text_headline: H. R. OCAMPO'S GENESIS
text_description: Genesis by H. R. Ocampo is made into the tapestry show curtain of the Main Theater (later, Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo) of the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

text_headline: FIRST RIZAL MONUMENT IN DAET
text_description: The first Rizal Monument in the Philippines is completed at Daet, Camarines Norte.

text_headline: KATIPUNAN FLAG
text_description: Hybrid images of precolonial letters and masonic emblems are used in the Katipunan flags, inspired by the masonic ideas of Andres Bonifacio.

text_headline: RECONSTRUCTION AND REHABILITATION
text_description: Reconstruction and Rehabilitation, 1943, by Gregorio Sibug depicts workers setting up the foundation of a new house as symbolism for starting anew out of the ashes of the war.

text_headline: AMORSOLO PAINTS FOR VARGAS
text_description: Amorsolo paints commissioned portraits and landscape paintings for Jorge B. Vargas, such as Harvest Scene and Fishing Scene, 1942.

media_caption: Fernando Amorsolo, Rizal Avenue on Fire, 1945
text_headline: AMORSOLO'S WAR SCENES
text_description: Amorsolo records war scenes such as Rizal Avenue on Fire, 1945, Ruins of the Manila Cathedral, 1945, and San Sebastian Church through Quiapo Ruins, 1945.

media_caption: Jaime de Guzman, Gomburza, 1970
text_headline: JAIME DE GUZMAN'S GOMBURZA
text_description: Gomburza by Jaime de Guzman (b. 1942) uses history to comment on contemporary issues by painting the martyrdom of the three priests killed by the Spanish colonizers in 1872.

media_caption: Tikbalang, Peace-loving Tikbalang, Solomon Saprid, 1971
text_headline: SOLOMON SAPRID'S TIKBALANG
text_description: Tikbalang by Solomon Saprid (1917-2003) presents a metal sculpture of a half-man, half-horse being based on a Filipino folk belief.

media_caption: Pasyon at Rebolusyon, Santiago Bose, 1983, Mixed media
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Peggy Bose)
text_headline: SANTI BOSE'S PASYON AT REBOLUSYON
text_description: Santi Bose (1949-2002) creates the installation Pasyon at Rebolusyon, which explores the theme of nativist millenarian faith, using indigenous and organic materials.

media_caption: Two Nuns of Edsa, Pete Reyes, 1986, The Manila Times
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of The Manila Times)
text_headline: TWO NUNS OF EDSA
text_description: Two Nuns of Edsa by photojournalist Pete Reyes becomes an iconic image of the EDSA Revolt.

text_headline: The Academia de Dibujo y Pintura, the first school for the visual arts, is founded by Damian Domingo (ca 1795-1834).
text_description: The Academia de Dibujo y Pintura, the first school for the visual arts, is founded by Damian Domingo (ca 1795-1834).

media_caption: Botanical illustrations from Manuel Blanco’s Flora de Filipinas, 1878, Real Jardin Botanico de Madrid Collection (manga)
media_credit: Real Jardin Botanico de Madrid Collection
text_headline: Fr Manuel Blanco’s (1778 – 1845) Flora de Filipinas is first published with no illustrations.
text_description: Fr Manuel Blanco’s (1778 – 1845) Flora de Filipinas is first published with no illustrations. Later editions in 1877-1883 feature illustrations of the plants studied by Fr. Blanco, rendered by Filipino artists.

media_caption: Lorenzo Atlas, Nuestra Señora del Rosario
text_description: Lorenzo Atlas (active 1738-1771) does the engraving of the La Naval.

media_caption: Kuan-yin Nuestra Señora del Rosario, 1825
media_credit: (San Agustin Museum/Photo by Kiko del Rosario)
text_headline: Kuan-Yin Nuestra Señora del Rosario, is created by Boholano painters
text_description: Kuan-Yin Nuestra Señora del Rosario, is created by Boholano painters, similar to the image of Kuanyin, the Chinese goddess of mercy.

media_caption: Lorenzo Guerrero, El Fuego, 1889
text_headline: The Academia de Dibujo y Pintura re-opens and promotes the academic style of painting under Spanish teachers
text_description: The Academia de Dibujo y Pintura re-opens and promotes the academic style of painting under Spanish teachers such as Agustin Saez (1828-1891) and Lorenzo Rocha (1837-1898). A Filipino student Lorenzo Guerrero (1835-1904) eventually becomes a teacher.

media_caption: Ilustracion Filipina, Periodico Quincenal
text_headline: La Ilustracion Filipina, published 1859-1860, and 1882, features lithographs of landscapes and genre scenes by Filipino artists.
text_description: La Ilustracion Filipina, published 1859-1860, and 1882, features lithographs of landscapes and genre scenes by Filipino artists.

text_headline: The subject of the earliest known photograph in the Philippines are the Tingguian of Abra, done in 1860.
text_description: The subject of the earliest known photograph in the Philippines are the Tingguian of Abra, done in 1860.

text_headline: Escuela Superior de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado is established and will operate until 1898.
text_description: Escuela Superior de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado is established and will operate until 1898.

media_caption: Spanish-era Fajardo bahay na bato in Bacolor, Pampanga
media_credit: (Center for Kapampangan Studies, Holy Angel University)
text_headline: The new mestizo elite commission portraits, landscapes, and bodegones for their houses called bahay na bato.
text_description: The new mestizo elite commission portraits, landscapes, and bodegones for their houses called bahay na bato.

media_caption: The Quiason Family 1880, Simon Flores
text_headline: Using the miniaturismo style, Simon Flores (1839-1904) paints Familia Quiason, 1880
text_description: Using the miniaturismo style, Simon Flores (1839-1904) paints Familia Quiason, 1880, detailing the embroidery of the clothes, jewelry, and interiors of the family home.

media_caption: Paz Paterno, Bodegon, 1884
text_headline: Bodegon, 1884, by Paz Paterno (1867-1914) features a landscape and still life of fruits.
text_description: Bodegon, 1884, by Paz Paterno (1867-1914) features a landscape and still life of fruits.

text_headline: Neoromanesque or Romanesque revival begins in the mid-19th century and continues to the next.
text_description: Neoromanesque or Romanesque revival begins in the mid-19th century and continues to the next. The style will be seen in many Philippine churches.
Beyond Art, written and designed by Rodolfo Paras-Perez (1934-2011), demonstrates the many imaginative possibilities of book design.
Carlos “Botong” Francisco and Guillermo Tolentino receive the National Artist award.
Ramon Valera is proclaimed National Artist for Fashion Design for his work on the Filipino terno.
Artist-volunteers are recruited into the Visual Art committees of NCCA and a series of regional and national congresses begin.

media_caption: Walang katapusang paghalo ng balat sa tinalupan, Brenda Fajardo, 1987
text_headline: Brenda Fajardo receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
text_description: Brenda Fajardo receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.

media_caption: Banton burial cloth
text_description: Ikat weave becomes prevalent in Southeast Asia in the 14th - 15th century, as evidenced by the Banton Burial Cloth, found in Banton Cave, Romblon in 1939.

media_caption: Santo Niño de Cebu, Early 16th Century
media_credit: (Photo from The Augustinian Province of Santo Niño de Cebu-Philippines Provincialate Offices)
text_headline: The Santo Nino de Cebu, a sculptural image of the Infant Jesus, is gifted by Magellan to Hara Amihan, the wife of Rajah Humabon.
text_description: The Santo Nino de Cebu, a sculptural image of the Infant Jesus, is gifted by Magellan to Hara Amihan, the wife of Rajah Humabon. She is baptized with the Christian name, Juana.

text_headline: Roberto Chabet, the Talaandig School for Living Traditions, and Ben Farrales receive the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
text_description: Roberto Chabet, the Talaandig School for Living Traditions, and Ben Farrales receive the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.

text_headline: Francisco Coching receives the National Artist award.
text_description: Francisco Coching receives the National Artist award.

text_headline: The Metrobank Foundation Alice Guillermo Award for Art Criticism is instituted.
text_description: The Metrobank Foundation Alice Guillermo Award for Art Criticism is instituted.

text_headline: The Purita Kalaw Ledesma Prize for Art Criticism is instituted by the Ateneo Art Gallery and the Kalaw Ledesma Foundation Inc.
text_description: The Purita Kalaw Ledesma Prize for Art Criticism is instituted by the Ateneo Art Gallery and the Kalaw Ledesma Foundation Inc.

text_headline: Journey of a Thousand Shuttles by Norma Respicio is published.
text_description: Journey of a Thousand Shuttles by Norma Respicio is published.

text_headline: Art Fair Philippines is founded.
text_description: Art Fair Philippines is founded.

text_headline: Bastards of Misrepresentation is curated by Manuel Ocampo in Hong Kong.
text_description: Bastards of Misrepresentation is curated by Manuel Ocampo in Hong Kong. It showcases the diverse practices explored by Filipino avant-garde artists like Poklong Anading, Yason Banal, Argie Bandoy, Bea Camacho, Lena Cobangbang, Louie Cordero, Maria Cruz, Gaston Damag, Arvin Flores, Dina Gadia, Robert Langenegger, Romeo Lee, Pow Martinez, Jayson Oliveria, Carlo Ricafort, Gerardo Tan, MM Yu, and Maria-Jeona Zoleta.

text_headline: The book Edades: From Freedom to Fruition is published
text_description: The book Edades: From Freedom to Fruition is published in conjunction with the retrospective exhibition on National Artist Victorio Edades at the CCP.

media_caption: Inabel weaver Magdalena Gamayo, Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan awardee, 2012
media_credit: (Photo from NCCA)
text_headline: The GAMABA is awarded to Magdalena Gamayo (b. 1924) for Ilocano inabel weaving and Teofilo Garcia (b. 1941) for kattukong hat making.
text_description: The GAMABA is awarded to Magdalena Gamayo (b. 1924) for Ilocano inabel weaving and Teofilo Garcia (b. 1941) for kattukong hat making.

text_headline: Philippine Ancestral Gold is published by the Ayala Foundation, authored by Florina Capistrano-Baker, John Guy, and John Miksic.
text_description: Philippine Ancestral Gold is published by the Ayala Foundation, authored by Florina Capistrano-Baker, John Guy, and John Miksic.

media_caption: Esteban Villanueva, Basi Revolt, 9th of 14 paintings depicting the bloody battle at Bantaoay, 1821
media_credit: National Museum of the Philippines collection
text_headline: Esteban Villanueva (1797-1878) is commissioned to do the Basi Revolt Series commemorating the Ilocano Basi revolt in 1807.
text_description: Esteban Villanueva (1797-1878) is commissioned to do the Basi Revolt Series commemorating the Ilocano Basi revolt in 1807.

media_caption: Kawayan de Guia in collaboration with Baguio community, Axis Tent, 2011
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Asia-Europe Foundation)
text_headline: The AXIS Art Project is launched in Baguio City, initiated by artist Kawayan de Guia.
text_description: The AXIS Art Project is launched in Baguio City, initiated by artist Kawayan de Guia. AXIS focuses on projects such as art festivals evoking collective memory and communities.

media_caption: Damian Domingo, Coleccion de Trajes de Manila y de las Provincias, illustration of A Mestizo Student from Manila
text_headline: Coleccion de Trajes de Manila Y de Las Provincias, ca 1835, by Damian Domingo
text_description: Coleccion de Trajes de Manila Y de Las Provincias, ca 1835, by Damian Domingo, depicts tipos del pais or types of Filipinos, based on class, race, and ethnicity, as seen in their costumes.

media_caption: Jose Dans, El Cielo, El Paraiso, El Purgatorio y El Infierno, 1850
text_headline: El Cielo, el Paraiso, el Purgatorio y el Infierno, a mural painting attributed to Jose Dans (1805-1888), is installed in Paete church
text_description: El Cielo, el Paraiso, el Purgatorio y el Infierno, a mural painting attributed to Jose Dans (1805-1888), is installed in Paete church; it is an example of a catechetical church painting.

media_caption: Martha Atienza, Gilubong ang Akon Pusod sa Dagat, 2011
media_credit: (Photos from the artist)
text_headline: Martha Atienza creates Gilubong Ang Akon Pusod Sa Dagat
text_description: Martha Atienza creates Gilubong Ang Akon Pusod Sa Dagat, a video art installation which juxtaposes the related lives of seafarers and the fishing community. The work wins the 2012 Ateneo Art Awards.

media_caption: Jose Honorato Lozano, Francisco Garcia Ortiz, 1854-63
text_headline: Francisco Garcia Ortiz by Jose Honorato Lozano (1821-1885) exemplifies the minituarized form of painting called letras y figuras patronized by the mestizo class and foreigners looking for souvenirs.
text_description: Francisco Garcia Ortiz by Jose Honorato Lozano (1821-1885) exemplifies the minituarized form of painting called letras y figuras patronized by the mestizo class and foreigners looking for souvenirs.

media_caption: Antonio Malantic, Inocencia Francia, 1876
text_headline: Antonio Malantic (1821-1886) paints the portraits of Soledad and Inocencia Francia, 1870
text_description: Antonio Malantic (1821-1886) paints the portraits of Soledad and Inocencia Francia, 1870, which depict young ladies of the mestizo class clothed in formal clothing with delicate embroidery.

media_caption: Adelaida Paterno, Country Scene, 1880s
text_headline: Embroidery work using hair in embroidery of a landscape scene
text_description: Embroidery work using hair in embroidery of a landscape scene, such as the Country Scene by Adelaida Paterno (1880-1962), is taught in the colegios for women.

media_caption: Art nouveau four-poster bed by Eduardo Ah Tay
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Leon Gallery)
text_headline: Ah Tay furniture becomes popular with its distinctive design for beds, cabinet, dining table and long seats.
text_description: Ah Tay furniture becomes popular with its distinctive design for beds, cabinet, dining table and long seats.

media_caption: Francisco Verano, Bamboo Fugue I, 1980
text_headline: FRANCISCO VERANO'S BAMBOO FUGUE
text_description: Bamboo Fugue by Francisco Verano (b. 1938), an example of bamboo sculpture, is created.
Santa Catalina, a beaterio, is founded. In the 19th century; the nuns of Santa Catalina will teach embroidery to their students.

media_caption: Morning Dip, 1961, by Fernando Amorsolo, the first National Artist for visual arts in 1972
media_credit: (Copyright owned by Fernando C. Amorsolo Art Foundation, Inc)
text_headline: FIRST NATIONAL ARTIST AWARD
text_description: The first National Artist award is posthumously given to Fernando Amorsolo.

media_caption: Poleteismo, Mideo Cruz, 2011, installation
media_credit: (Photo from the artist)
text_headline: Kulo exhibit at the CCP is forced to close due to protests that arose with regards to Poleteismo by Mideo Cruz (b. 1973)
text_description: Kulo exhibit at the CCP is forced to close due to protests that arose with regards to Poleteismo by Mideo Cruz (b. 1973), an installation work that juxtaposes religiosity and politics.

media_caption: Jose Tence Ruiz, Shoal, 2015, a velvet assemblage later exhibited at the 56th Venice Biennale
media_credit: (Photo from the artist)
text_headline: The Philippines participates again in the 56th Venice Biennale
text_description: The Philippines participates again in the 56th Venice Biennale, with a team made up of curator Patrick Flores, artists Manny Montelibano (b. 1971), Chabet, and Jose Tence Ruiz under a curatorial platform Tie a String Around the World, featuring the work of Manuel Conde and Carlos “Botong” Francisco.
Crucible Workshop publishes Art Philippines, edited by Juan T. Gatbonton, Jeannie E. Javelosa, and Lourdes Ruth R. Roa.

media_caption: Zhangzhou tradeware
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Oriental Ceramic Society of the Philippines)
text_headline: Chinese porcelain
text_description: Chinese porcelain and stoneware are traded in the Philippines during the Sung and Yuan periods, and this trade reaches its apex in the 13th century.

media_caption: Golden Tara of Agusan, 13th-14th century
media_credit: (Photo by John Weinstein, The Field Museum, Image No. A114678d_006A, Cat. No. 109928)
text_headline: The Golden Tara of Agusan
text_description: The Golden Tara of Agusan, crafted in the late 13th century and found in 1917, exemplifies the Hindu - Buddhist links of the period.

media_caption: Galo Ocampo, Flagellantes, 1953
text_description: Modern artists explore rooted expression modes such as Filipino-themed surrealism, as in Galo Ocampo’s Flagellants.
Monumental public sculptures are created by Eduardo Castrillo, exemplified by the People Power Monument at Libis, Quezon City.

media_caption: Doctrina Christiana en la Lengua Española y Tagala, 1593
text_headline: Doctrina Christiana
text_description: Doctrina Christiana, the first book printed in the Philippines using the xylographic method, is printed in both Spanish and Tagalog. It contains the illustration of Santo Domingo by a Chinese convert Juan de Vera.

media_caption: Our Lady of La Naval, detail, (Lady of the Navy) aka Nuestra Señora del Santisimo Rosario (Our Lady of the Most Holy Rosary). 1593
text_headline: La Naval
text_description: La Naval, a sculptural image of the Virgin Mary made of wood and ivory, is carved by a Chinese artisan from Ilocos. Products of the ivory carving tradition are eventually exported to Europe.
Fashion designer Ramon Valera (1912-1972) combines the baro and saya into one gown as women’s wear.
Gatbonton comes out with a comic strip called Jappy Days making fun of the Japanese in the most acerbic and inflammatory tone.

media_caption: Depiction of the Visayan pintados, ca 1590
media_credit: (Boxer Codex, The Lilly Library Digital Collections)
text_headline: The Boxer Codex
text_description: The Boxer Codex, ca 1590, depicts types of Filipinos in contemporary dress. It is believed to have been done by Chinese artisans. One image, the Pintados of the Visayas, features body tattoos as a form of dress.

media_caption: Trompe l’oeil paintings inside the San Agustin Church in Intramuros, Manila, 2014
media_credit: (Photos Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_headline: San Agustin Church in Intramuros
text_description: The Spanish plateresque retablo of San Agustin Church in Intramuros, said to be the earliest retablo of that church, is carved by Juan de los Santos.

media_caption: (IESVS es clauado enla Cruz), Copper engraving by Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay, 1760
media_credit: (Photo from CCP)
text_headline: In the fifth edition (1760) of de Belen’s pasyon, Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay (ca 1701-1790) and Francisco Suarez (active 1716-1760) engrave illustrations of Christ’s life and passion.
text_description: In the fifth edition (1760) of de Belen’s pasyon, Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay (ca 1701-1790) and Francisco Suarez (active 1716-1760) engrave illustrations of Christ’s life and passion.

media_caption: Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, El Asesinato del Gobernador Bustamante y su Hijo, detail, late 19th century
media_credit: (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)
text_description: El Asesinato del Gobernador Fernando Bustamante Y Su Hijo, painted in the late 19th century by Hidalgo, depicts an anti-clerical subject matter which echoes ilustrado discourse on church corruption and governance.

media_caption: University of Santo Tomas College of Fine Arts and Design, 2016
media_credit: (Laielani P. Arocha)
text_description: The University of Santo Tomas College of Fine Arts and Design is founded. Its first faculty consists of Victorio Edades, Jose L. de Ocampo, and Severino Fabie.

media_caption: Facade details of Church of Santo Tomas de Villanueva in Miag-ao, Iloilo, 2013
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_headline: The relief carving on the façade of Miag-ao Church in Iloilo, done in 1787, indigenizes the rococo tradition, as it features local plants, such as a banana and a coconut tree, in its facade carvings.
text_description: The relief carving on the façade of Miag-ao Church in Iloilo, done in 1787, indigenizes the rococo tradition, as it features local plants, such as a banana and a coconut tree, in its facade carvings.

media_caption: Print by Francisco Rodriguez depicting the tortures of hell, Ang Infiernong Nabubucsan sa Tauong Christiano, 1713
media_credit: National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_headline: The images of hell are engraved by Francisco Dominguez in the popular cathetical book Ang Infiernong Nabubucsan sa Taong Cristiano at Nang Houag Masoc Doon.
text_description: The images of hell are engraved by Francisco Dominguez in the popular cathetical book Ang Infiernong Nabubucsan sa Taong Cristiano at Nang Houag Masoc Doon.

media_caption: Ibarra de la Rosa, The Garden, 1975
media_credit: Cultural Center of the Philippines Collection
text_description: In the 1970s, the impressionist style is promoted by the Dimasalang Group composed of Sofronio Mendoza, Emilio Aguilar Cruz, Romulo Galicano, and Ibarra de la Rosa.

media_caption: Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, La Banca, 1876 Eleuterio M. Pascual Collection
media_credit: (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)
text_description: La Banca by Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo (1855-1913) is chosen for the Philadelphia Universal Exposition.

media_caption: Las Virgenes Cristianas Expuestas Al Populacho, Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, 1884
text_description: Spoliarium by Luna and Hidalgo’s Virgenes Christianas Expuestas al Populacho are interpreted as alluding to the oppression of the Philippine colony by Spain.
Napoleon Abueva and Victorio Edades receive the National Artist award.
A Heritage of Saints by Esperanza Bunag-Gatbonton (b. 1938) is published.
Philippine Religious Carvings in Ivory by Esperanza Bunag-Gatbonton is published.

media_caption: Pan-ay Bell, 1878, Bronze, Juan Reina, Fr Jose Beloso
media_credit: (Photo by Iannekleina)
text_description: The Pan-ay Bell is cast by Juan Reina in Pan-ay, Capiz. Commissioned by Fr Jose Beloso, the bell is reputed to be the largest in Asia.
Museum of Contemporary Art and Design Manila is launched at the College of Saint Benilde.

media_caption: Spolarium, Juan Luna, 1884
media_credit: (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)
text_description: Luna and Hidalgo win gold and silver medals at the Madrid Exposition, which further fuels the Propaganda Movement discourse of “reform” and racial equality.
The National Museum, formerly called the Insular Museum of Ethnology, National History and Commerce, is founded.

media_caption: Virgen sa Balintawak, ca 1900
text_description: In the spirit of Filipinization, western iconography is appropriated through the Virgen ng Balintawak, ca 1905, of the Aglipayan church.

media_caption: Salakab or fishtrap attributed to Pangasinan
media_credit: (Philippine Basketry: An Appreciation by Robert F. Lane. The Bookmark, Inc, 1986.)
text_description: Robert Lane writes Philippine Basketry.

media_caption: President Manuel L. Quezon, 1948 by Fernando Amorsolo
media_credit: (Copyright owned by the Fernando C. Amorsolo Art Foundation, Inc)
text_description: Fernando Amorsolo paints the official portrait of President Quezon, as well as portraits of other major figures like US Resident Commissioner Paul McNutt and Executive Secretary Jorge Vargas.

media_caption: Photograph of a Wedding, Felix Laureano, Recuerdos de Filipinas, 1895
media_credit: (Photo from Digital Library @ Villanova University)
text_description: Recuerdos de Filipinas by Felix Laureano is the first collection of photographs by a Filipino. It features genre scenes and dress at the time.

media_caption: Primeras Letras, Simon Flores, 1890
text_description: Primeras Letras by Simon Flores (1839-1904) exemplifies genre paintings in the academic style.

media_caption: Santos-Bautista House, 2017
media_credit: (Kiko del Rosario)
text_description: Sculptures in the form of caryatids are seen in some bahay na bato ancestral houses in Bulacan and Escolta.

media_caption: Bagobo community
media_credit: (The Philippines Past and Present by Dean Worcester. The MacMillan Company, 1914.)
text_description: Photo-ethnography provides images of Filipinos as “primitive” under the auspices of Commissioner Dean Worcester from 1902 to 1907.

media_caption: Harry Harnish, Captain Alex Davis’ Child and Nurse, Between 1898 and 1907. Photo no. 27 of the album “Poses and Exposures,”
media_credit: The Philippines Through the Lens of an American Soldier: The Harry Harnish Photographic Collection.
text_description: American photographer Harry Harnish (1869-1960) takes photos of locals from 1898 to 1907.

media_caption: Prewar Manila Metropolitan Theater facade
media_credit: (Leo Cloma Collection)
text_description: Francesco Monti (1888-1958) designs the sculptural elements of the Metropolitan Theater, 1931, using art deco designs to complement the architectural designs of Juan Arellano.

media_caption: Tuklas Sining monographs on architecture
media_credit: (Covers courtesy of Cultural Center of the Philippines)
text_description: CCP launches the first seven monographs and videos on the seven arts edited by Nicanor Tiongson called The Tuklas Sining series. Twenty-one more videos and monographs will complete the 28-part series in 1994. A coffee-table book Tuklas Sining will collect and illustrate the first seven monographs in 1992.

media_caption: CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, Volume III, Philippine Architecture, Publications on general survey of Philippine architecture
media_credit: (Book covers courtesy of Cultural Center of the Philippines, University of San Carlos, and University of the Philippines Press)
text_description: The CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art is published, edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson, with one whole volume dedicated to the Visual Arts, edited by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Alice Guillermo, and Santiago Pilar. INACCURATE/RELATED

media_caption: Ramon Orlina, Treasure Trove, 2006
media_credit: (Photos from Museo Orlina)
text_description: Ramon Orlina (b. 1944) conducts his first exhibit Reflections, using glass as his medium for sculptural work.

media_caption: EZ Izon, Military Rule Next?, 1972
media_credit: (Photo from the Presidential Communications Development and Strategic Planning Office)
text_description: Philippine Free Press publishes the editorial cartoon Military Rule Next? by EZ Izon (1911-mid-1990s).

media_caption: San Clemente Festival/ The Fluvial Festival of Angono, Jose Blanco, 1984
text_description: Folk genre paintings flourish in Angono, Tanay, and Binangonan, giving rise to painters such as Jose Blanco (1932 -2008), Salvador Juban, Nemesio Miranda, and Vicente Reyes.

media_caption: Tinguians, Manuel Rodriguez Jr., 1978
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Marcelino Rodriguez)
text_description: Tingguians by Manuel Rodriguez Jr explores tapestry work and printmaking.

media_caption: Turn of the Century, Gilda Cordero-Fernando, Nik Ricio
media_credit: (Photos of book covers courtesy of Felice Sta. Maria, GCF Books, and Studio 5 Designs Inc)
text_description: The book Turn of the Century is published, edited by Gilda Cordero-Fernando and designed by Nik Ricio (b. 1946).

media_caption: The 1980 Mobil Art Awards, Alice Guillermo
media_credit: (Photos of book covers courtesy of Mobil Oil, Art Association of the Philippines, Ateneo Art Gallery, Cultural Center of the Philippines, and Metrobank Foundation)
text_description: The Mobil Art Awards starts with its first batch of winners: Joya, Danilo Dalena, Ang Kiukok, Romulo Olazo (1934-2015), and Mauro Malang Santos.

media_caption: Juan Luna, The Filipino as Painter, Santiago Albano Pilar
media_credit: (Photo of book cover courtesy of Eugenio Lopez Foundation, Inc)
text_description: Santiago Pilar (b. 1946) writes Juan Luna: The Filipino as Painter, published by the Eugenio Lopez Foundation.

media_caption: Wood things, Junyee, 1981
media_credit: (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)
text_description: Wood Things by Junyee (b. 1942) exemplifies installation art made of kapok or cotton pods, installed on the walls and floor of the CCP.

media_caption: Antipas Delotavo, Itak sa Puso ni Mang Juan, 1978
text_description: Ang Itak sa Puso ni Mang Juan by Antipas Delotavo is painted to show the plight of Filipino workers oppressed by multinational companies.

media_caption: El Violoncellista, Miguel Zaragoza, The Cellist, 1891
text_description: Winners in the art competitions during the St. Louis Exposition are Hidalgo, Fabian de la Rosa (1869-1937), Miguel Zaragoza(1842-1923), Vicente Rivera y Mir (1872-1954), Patricio Gaston O’Farrell (1879 -1942), and Jorge Pineda (1879 -1946).

media_caption: Vista Parcial de Angono y Laguna de Bay,(Partial View of Angono and Laguna Bay) Juan Senson, 1850s
text_description: Local elites would patronize visual artists in the regions such as Juan Senson (1864-1924) and Pedro Piñon of Angono, as well as the religious art of the santero and carroza making in Pampanga, through the works of Maximo Vicente and other santeros.

media_caption: Ramon Martinez, Balintawak Monument, 1911
media_credit: (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)
text_description: Homenaje del Pueblo Filipino a los Heroes del ’96 aka Cry of Balintawak by Ramon Martinez (1869-1950) becomes the first concrete full-figure sculpture of a revolutionary figure, assumed to be the figure of Andres Bonifacio. The sculpture has been installed in UP Diliman since 1967.

media_caption: The University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts first director, Fabian de la Rosa, seated, with eminent professors, left to right: Pablo Amorsolo, Irineo Miranda, Teodoro Buenaventura, Toribio Herrera, Ramon Peralta Sr, Vicente Rivera y Mir, Guillermo Tolentino, Fernando Amorsolo, and Ambrosio Morales
media_credit: (Photo from CCP)
text_description: Fabian de la Rosa goes to Europe in 1908-1910 under a pensionado scholarship. He joins the faculty of UP SFA and will later become its director (1925-35), after Rafael Enriquez.

media_caption: Planting Rice, Fernando Amorsolo, 1921
media_credit: (Copyright owned by Fernando C. Amorsolo Art Foundation, Inc)
text_description: Fabian de la Rosa and Fernando Amorsolo paint their own versions of Planting Rice, presenting an idealized view of peasant life. Landscape and genre paintings continue to be popular for the tourist market and art patrons.

media_caption: Victorio Edades, The Builders, 1928
text_description: Victorio Edades mounts an exhibition at the Philippine Columbian Club, espousing modernism in art, with works such as The Builders and The Sketch.

media_caption: Guillermo Tolentino, Bonifacio Monument, 1933. Bronze
media_credit: (Photo from CCP)
text_description: Guillermo Tolentino creates the Bonifacio Monument, installed at Caloocan. It features a sculptural tableau of the events from the 1872 execution of the GomBurZa to the 1896 Katipunan Revolution, with Bonifacio at its head flanked by Emilio Jacinto and other revolutionaries.

media_caption: Ceiling paintings of Maribojoc Church in Bohol by Raymundo Francia
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library)
text_description: Juan Abelardo, Ramon Peralta (1877-1940), Toribio Antillon (1856-1913), and Emilio Alvero (1886-1955) are commissioned to paint scenography in the interior walls and ceilings of prominent houses in Manila and Bulacan. In Cebu and Bohol, Raymundo Francia and Canuto Avila, decorate church ceilings in 1920-1941.

media_caption: Mother Nature's Bounty Harvest, Victorio Edades, Carlos V. Francisco, Galo Ocampo, 1935
text_description: Edades forms the Triumvirate, composed of himself, Galo B. Ocampo (1913-1985), and Carlos V. Francisco, to execute mural commissions using an Art Deco/Modernist style for projects by Juan Nakpil, such as Rising Philippines, 1934 (destroyed 1945), that decorated the lobby of the Capitol Theater in Escolta. They work on murals in public spaces, such as theaters and hospitals.
The First Manila Art Fair is organized.

media_caption: Jose Joya, Granadean Arabesque, 1958
media_credit: Ateneo Art Gallery Collection
text_description: The Shell National Students Art Competition (SNSAC) is launched. Among its awardees from 1956 to 1965 are Joya, Alcuaz, Ang Kiukok (1931-2005), Ong Bun Gian, Manuel Rodriguez Jr. (1942-2014), Veronica Lim (Yuyitung), and James Ong Le Pho. The award was halted during the 1970s and was later revived in 1989.

media_caption: Martino Abellana, Job Was Also Man, 1953
text_description: Job Was Also Man by Martino Abellana (1914-1988) wins first prize in the conservative category at the 1953 semiannual competition of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP).

media_caption: BenCab, Brown Brothers’ Burden, 1972
text_description: Bencab (b. 1942) begins creating the Larawan and Sabel series, exploring the image of the marginalized people in Philippine society, and contrasting the past with the present.

media_caption: Pilipino Komiks, Kontra-Bida, 1955
media_credit: Photos from the Dennis S. Villegas Collection, komiksph, and The Life and Art of Francisco Coching by Patrick Flores et al. Vibal Foundation, 2009
text_description: Don Ramon Roces and Tony Velasquez organize Ace Publications which puts out Pilipino Komiks, 1947, Tagalog Klasiks, 1949; Hiwaga Komiks, 1950; Espesyal Komiks and Kenkoy Komiks, 1952. These comic books flourish until the 1980s. Some stories from the komiks eventually are adopted into films.

media_caption: Carlos V. Francisco, Kaingin, 1948, first-prize winner at the first national art competition organized by the Art Association of the Philippines
media_credit: Solita Camara-Besa Collection
text_description: The Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) is launched in 1948. Annual and semi-annual competitions begin with the first winners: Carlos “Botong’ Francisco, first prize for Kaingin; Demetrio Diego, second prize for Capas; Vicente Manansala, third prize for Banaklaot; Cesar Legaspi, fourth prize for Sick Child; Diosdado Lorenzo, fifth prize for Japanese Inhumanities; H.R. Ocampo, sixth prize for Nude with Candle and Flower.

media_caption: Cesar Legaspi, Gadgets, 1947
text_description: Cesar Legaspi paints The Gadgets, evoking human labor and its dehumanization in an industrial setting.

media_caption: Napoloen Abueva, Kaganapan, 1952
text_description: Kaganapan by Napoleon Abueva (1930 – 2018) wins the grand prize at the AAP annual competition and is considered a breakthrough in Philippine sculpture, as it veers away from the classical traditions and employs neorealism in its figuration.

media_caption: Constancio Bernardo, Wildflower Series II, 1977
media_credit: Bernardo Family Collection (Photos by At Maculangan/Pioneer Studios)
text_description: Artists who explore abstract expressionism include Constancio Bernardo (1913-2003), Cenon Rivera, Arturo Luz (b. 1926), Victor Oteyza, Fernando Zobel (1924-1984), Federico Alcuaz (1932-2001), and Lee Aguinaldo.

media_caption: Abdulmari Asia Imao, Sarimanok Crescent Series II, 2012
media_credit: (Photo from Art+Magazine)
text_description: The first solo exhibition by Abdulmari Asia Imao (1936-2014) is held in 1960 at the Contemporary Art gallery in Mabini. His work explores Islamic motifs such as the sarimanok, okir, and Arabic calligraphy as idiom for his works.

The First Sungdu-an National Visual Art Exhibition is held with curators Bobi Valenzuela, Virgilio Aviado, and Imelda Cajipe-Endaya aiming to provide a platform for artists and curators from the regions.

media_caption: David Medalla in San Francisco, ca 1960s
media_credit: (Photo from Planting Rice)
text_description: Performance art is done by the Arts Laboratory group composed of David Medalla, Jun Terra, Lazaro Soriano, Marciano Galang (b. 1945), Alan Rivera (1941 -2015), and Red Mansueto. The works are improvisational and participatory, and done unannounced in public places such as Luneta Park, at the open spaces of the Cultural Center of the Philippines complex, in cafes and other gathering places.

media_caption: Larry Alcala, Slice of Life, 1983, UP Diliman
media_credit: (Photo by John Paul Olivares)
text_description: Larry Alcala (1926 – 2002), Mauro Malang Santos, Corky Trinidad, Nonoy Marcelo (b. 1942), and Danilo Dalena (b. 1942) are the most active in the field of komiks, creating witty satire on the political and social conditions of the country.

media_caption: Roberto Chabet, Untitled, 1974, from the Bakawan series
media_credit: Cultural Center of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Roberto Chabet’s (1937-2013) first exhibit is at the Luz Gallery, ushering in conceptual art in the Philippines.

media_caption: Federico Aguilar Alcuaz, Nude, 1981 Private collection
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Leon Gallery and Christian Aguilar)
text_description: The first solo exhibition of Federico Alcuaz, (1932-2011), known for his tapestries and abstract paintings, is held.

media_caption: Carlos V. Francisco, Filipino Struggles Through History, detail, 1964
text_description: Filipino Struggles Through History by Carlos “Botong” Francisco is installed at the City of Manila Katipunan Hall, depicting the visual narrative of the history of Manila on all four walls.

media_caption: Napoloen Abueva, Allegorical Harpoon, 1964
media_credit: Cultural Center of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Allegorical Harpoon by Napoleon Abueva, a modernist who challenged conventions in classical sculpture, is created and later acquired by the CCP.

media_caption: J. Elizalde Navarro, Homage to Dodgie Laurel, 1966
text_description: Homage to Dodgie Laurel by J. Elizalde Navarro (1924-1999) is an assemblage using found objects and metal parts.

media_caption: Ang Kiukok, Crucifixion, 1968
text_description: Crucifixion, an expressionistic image of the tortured human condition, is painted by Ang Kiukok.

media_caption: PUJ, 1970, by Antonio Austria, CCP Thirteen Artists awardee, 1970
media_credit: Cultural Center of the Philippines Collection
text_description: The second generation modernists such as Jose Joya, Ang Kiukok, Mauro Malang Santos (b. 1928), Antonio Austria (b. 1936), Angelito Antonio (b. 1939), and Juvenal Sanso (b. 1929) rise to prominence.

media_caption: Marcos bust before1986
media_credit: (Photos courtesy of Nicanor G. Tiongson and Inquirer.net)
text_description: The colossal Marcos Monument is created by the government in La Union, in the ancestral lands of the Ibaloi. It is damaged in 1989 by a blast reportedly done by the New People’s Army. It is subsequently destroyed in 2002 by bomb blasts from suspected treasure hunters.

media_caption: Renato Habulan, Kagampan, 1983
media_credit: (Photo from the artist)
text_description: Protest art intensifies with paintings and murals exhibited at the first Makiisa Festival. Social realist paintings are done, like Habulan’s large-scale painting Kagampan, depicting the struggle of workers and peasants, Baens Santos’s Malumbay si Ina, and Doloricon’s Hinagpis.

media_caption: Edgar Talusan Fernandez, Hanap ay Laya, 1984
text_description: Protest art continues with Baens Santos’s Alay sa Bagong Bayani and Fernandez’s Hanap ay Laya, both expressing the people’s aspiration for freedom and sovereignty. The clenched fist motif becomes popular in symbolizing militancy and defiance, as in Al Manrique’s Hand Series.

media_caption: Lazaro Soriano, Jak en Poy, 1987
text_description: Jak en Poy, a playful interpretation of the historic EDSA Revolt by Lazaro Soriano (b. 1943), is painted.

media_caption: Uma ti Biag/Archetype, A Cordillera Labyrinth, Roberto Villanueva, 1989
media_credit: (Photos courtesy of Japan Foundation and Angel Velasco Shaw)
text_description: Roberto Villanueva (1947-1994) installs the open-air labyrinth Uma ti Biag at the CCP grounds.

media_caption: H.R. Ocampo’s Circe, 1969
media_credit: Cultural Center of the Philippines Collection
text_description: H.R. Ocampo receives the National Artist award.

media_caption: Kalinga-Apayao man and woman by Wig Tysmans
media_credit: (Photo from Pastor-Roces 1991)
text_description: Sinaunang Habi: Philippine Ancestral Weave is authored by Marian Pastor Roces (b. 1953), with photography by Dick Baldovino (1937-2007) and Wig Tysman (b. 1953).

media_caption: UGATLahi Artist Collective, Manananggal, 2007
media_credit: (Photo from the artist collective)
text_description: UGATLahi, a collective of progressive artists and activists, is founded.

media_caption: Sanggawa Art Collective, Epilogo, 1998 Del Monte Collection
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Mark Justiniani and Joy Mallari)
text_description: Artist group Sanggawa (1994 -2000) is organized by Elmer Borlongan (b. 1967), Karen Flores (b. 1966), Mark Justiniani (b. 1966), Joy Mallari, and Federico Sievert. It aims to revitalize mural art through collective work.

media_caption: Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo and the Generation of 1872, Alfredo Roces
media_credit: (Photos of book covers courtesy of Heritage, Eugenio Lopez Foundation, Onion & Chives, and Vibal Foundation)
text_description: Alfredo Roces (b. 1923) publishes Felix Resurrecion Hidalgo and the Generation of 1872.

media_caption: Antipas Delotavo, Dantaon, 1998
media_credit: Charlie Cojuangco Collection (Photo from the artist)
text_description: Antipas Delotavo paints Dantaon, which offers a critical view of the narrative of Philippine history.

media_caption: Painting History, revisions in philippine colonial art, Patrick D. Flores
media_credit: (Photos of book covers courtesy of Vera-Reyes, Cultural Center of the Philippines, National Commission for Culture and the Arts, and UP Press)
text_description: Painting History: Revisions in Philippine Colonial Art by Patrick Flores (b. 1969) is published, offering a postcolonial perspective in reading Philippine art.

media_caption: Bagobo inabal weaver, Salinta Monon, Gawad sa Manililikha ng Bayan awardee, 1998
media_credit: (Photo by Renato S. Rastrollo, NCCA)
text_description: · Salinta Monon (1920-2009) and Lang Dulay (1924-2015) receive the GAMABA award for Bagobo textile weaving and Tboli t’nalak weaving, respectively.

media_caption: Protest/Revolutionary Art in the Philippine 1970-1990, Alice G. Guillermo
media_credit: (Photos of book covers courtesy of Vera-Reyes, Cultural Center of the Philippines, National Commission for Culture and the Arts, and UP Press)
text_description: Alice Guillermo writes Protest: Revolutionary Art in the Philippines, 1970-1990, an important contribution in establishing the history of the art of the protest movement in the Philippines.

media_caption: Neo-Angono Art Collective, Sangandaan ng Kasaysayan ng Malayang Pamamahayag sa Pilipinas, 2007, original mural, top, and altered portions
media_credit: (Photo from the artist collective)
text_description: The Neo-Angono Artists Collective is founded in Rizal province with members who are visual artists, writers, musicians, theater workers, filmmakers, critics, and researchers. They organize the Neo-Angono Public Art Festival annually which features installation pieces and performance art.

media_caption: Poklong Anading, Ocular, 2009
media_credit: (Photo from the artist)
text_description: The video installation Ocular by Poklong Anading (1975) is exhibited in Some Rooms held at Osage Gallery. It explores the condition of migrant workers in Hong Kong.

media_caption: Vicente Alvarez Dizon, After the Day’s Toil, 1938
media_credit: Rogelio Pine Collection (Photo courtesy of Josie Dizon Henson)
text_description: After a Day’s Toil by Vicente Alvarez Dizon (1905-1947) wins the top prize in the Golden Gate International Exposition, California in 1939. It wins over 77 other artworks, including that of Salvador Dali.

media_caption: Galo Ocampo, Brown Madonna, 1938
text_description: Brown Madonna by Galo Ocampo indigenizes the theme of Madonna and Child.
In the 1930s, furniture design, such as Juan Nakpil’s Ambassador Chair for Puyat & Sons, fashion, and industrial design are influenced by art deco.

media_caption: Album ng Kabalbalan ni Kenkoy, Tony Velasquez, Pre-World War II Kenkoy comic strip published in Liwayway
media_credit: (Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library)
text_description: Antonio S. Velasquez (1910-1997) and Romualdo Ramos publish the first issue of Mga Kababalaghan ni Kenkoy, in Liwayway magazine.

media_caption: Ulos, 1972/1973, Anthologies of socially oriented stories
media_credit: (University of the Philippines Press and Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)
text_description: The underground cultural magazine, Ulos, begins publication, and well-known social realists serve as illustrators.

media_caption: El Renacimiento, a politically oriented periodical
media_credit: (UP Diliman Main Library)
text_description: Weekly publications of Lipang Kalabaw, Philippines Free Press, and El Renacimiento, or dailies like The Independent, feature illustration work for editorial cartoons and artworks by Filipino artists.
Ray Albano’s (1947 -1985) Step on the Sand and Make Footprints is critically received at the International Biennial Exhibition of Prints in Tokyo.
The Filipino Engraving is written by Jesus Merino OP, Rod Paras-Perez, and Imelda Cajipe-Endaya.
Publication of The Struggle for Philippine Art by Purita Kalaw Ledesma (1914 -2004) and Amadis Ma. Guerrero strengthens the discourse on modern art in the Philippines.
Vicente Manansala receives the National Artist award.
The Central Bank publishes A Portfolio of 60 Philippine Art Masterpieces.
Francisco Coching and Pitoy Moreno are awarded the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.

media_caption: Main altar of the San Ignacio Church, from 150: The Ateneo Way by Jose S. Arcilla, SJ, 1937
media_credit: (Photo from 150: The Ateneo Way by Jose S. Arcilla, SJ. Media Wise Communications / Muse Books, 2009.)
text_description: The work of Isabelo Tampinco (1850-1933) in the San Ignacio Church, especially its interior decorations carved from 1882 to 1889, is hailed as a masterpiece in Philippine sculpture. This church is a collaborative work between Agustin Saez who crafted the design, Isabelo Tampinco who carved the ceiling, columns, and altar, and Crispulo Jocson who made the statues. It may be considered as an indigenized version of Art Nouveau style. The church was bombed in 1945 during WWII.

media_caption: Lipang Kalabaw, 27 July 1907
text_description: Commercial lithographic printing flourishes, especially under the Carmelo and Bauermann Press, where prints for flyers, posters, waybills, and illustrations were produced. Jorge Pineda becomes the chief illustrator of Lipang Kalabaw, under the nom de plume Makahiya.

media_caption: 1924 Manila Carnival poster by Fernando Amorsolo
media_credit: (Copyright owned by Fernando C. Amorsolo Art Foundation, Inc; photo from Amorsolo: 1892-1972 by Alfredo Roces. Filipinas Foundation, Inc, 1975.)
text_description: Jorge Pineda and Fernando Amorsolo (1892-1972), are commissioned to design posters for the Manila Carnival.
Fernando Amorsolo and Pablo Amorsolo serve as illustrators to the Philippine Reader series, and will influence the construction of the idealized way of life set in the countryside.

Debates between Conservatives, represented by Ariston Estrada, and the Moderns, through Edades, Galo Ocampo (1913-1985), Hernando R. Ocampo, Salvador Lopez, and Francisco Arcellana, are published in various weekly journals and newsletters, centering on issues of aesthetics and art history.
The Cebu Arts Association is formed led by Julian N. Jumalon along with Oscar Figuracion, Ricardo Avila, Fidel Araneta, Silvestre Orfelia, Emilio Olmos, and Jose Trinidad Alcoseba.

Edades declares the existence of the Thirteen Moderns of Philippine Art: Victorio Edades, Galo B. Ocampo, Diosdado Lorenzo, Carlos “Botong” Francisco, Vicente Manansala, Hernando R. Ocampo, Cesar Legaspi, Demetrio Diego (1909-1988), Jose Pardo (1916-2002), Ricarte Purugganan (1912-1998), Bonifacio Cristobal (1911-1977), Arsenio Capili (1914-1945), and Anita Magsaysay-Ho (1914-2012).
Art In Tagala, based on the Aurelio Alvero collection, is published.

media_caption: Diosdado Lorenzo, Rape and Massacre in Ermita, 1947
media_credit: National Museum of the Philippines Collection (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)
text_description: Artists, liberated from the Japanese, paint artworks that document the war: Doomed Family, 1945, by Dominador Castañeda (1904-1967); Capas, 1948, by Demetrio Diego (1909-1988); and Massacre in Ermita, Atrocities in Paco, and Execution at the Cemetery by Diosdado Lorenzo, all in 1947.

media_caption: Explosion No. 141, Lee Aguinaldo, 1957
media_credit: Ateneo Art Gallery Collection
text_description: The modernist style of Victorio Edades, Hernando Ocampo, Ramon Estella, Vicente Manansala, Victor Oteyza (1913-1979), Cesar Legaspi, and Romeo Tabuena (b. 1921) move towards abstraction. In the 1950s, artists who are working in this style and direction are referred to as the Neo-realists, a term which also includes Nena Saguil (1914-1994), Anita Magsaysay-Ho, Manuel Rodriguez Sr (1912 - 2017), Cenon Rivera (1922-1998), Jeremias Elizalde Navarro (1924-1999), Jose Joya (1931-1995), Lee Aguinaldo (1933 -2007), and David Cortez Medalla (b. 1938).

media_caption: Vicente Manansala, Madonna of the Slums
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Ronna Manansala)
text_description: Madonna of the Slums by Vicente Manansala, a key modernist painting that appropriates cubism to depict the poverty of the slum areas which arose after WWII, is painted. In 1951, he paints the Jeepneys, a study of the dense urban life in the Philippines, captured through the style of modernism.

PAG puts up The First Exhibition of Non-Objective Art as support for modern art. PAG also facilitates the first effort to break through the international art scene through an exhibition of paintings and sculptures of 21 artists, which travels to New York and Washington in 1953-1954.
Aurelio S. Alvero, who used the pseudonym Magtanggol Asa, writes the monograph of the First Exhibition of Non-Objective Art in Tagala.

Conservative artists walk out of AAP contests as protest to the perceived bias of the jury in awarding all the Rotary Club Golden Anniversary awards to modernists Galo Ocampo, Manuel Rodriguez Sr, and Vicente Manansala. The conservatives set up their exhibition in the Mabini area to cater to a tourist market, and establish what will be the Mabini Artists Association. The first generation Mabini artists include Gabriel Custodio (1912-1993), Simon Saulog (1916-1995), Miguel Galvez, Cesar Buenaventura, Cesar Amorsolo, Serafin Serna (1919-1979), Ben Alano (1920-1991), and Fermin V. Sanchez. A short-lived Academy of Fine Art is also founded which intends to act as foil to AAP’s perceived swing toward modernism.
Manuel Rodriguez Sr launches the Contemporary Art Gallery which definitively opens up the art world to printmaking.
Jaime Zobel de Ayala (b. 1934) publishes Philippine Religious Imagery, a survey of Spanish colonial religious culture based on extensive private collections.
The Philippines participates in the 32nd International Art Exhibition of the Venice Biennale 1964. Jose Joya and Napoleon Abueva are chosen to represent the country.
Philippine Art Educators Association (PAEA) is founded, under the leadership of artists Araceli Dans and Brenda Fajardo.
The Printmakers Association of the Philippines (PAP) is founded, under the leadership of Manuel Rodriguez Sr.
During the inauguration of the CCP, David Medalla stages a protest with the poet Jun Lansang and the visual artist Mars Galang inside the building itself.

Under Chabet and later Raymundo Albano, the CCP Museum opens its exhibition programming to works influenced by the western avant-garde and conceptual tenets, pop art, happenings, environmental assemblages, new realism, performance art, and sound works.
Philippine Association of Printmakers holds its first annual national graphic arts competition where Manuel Rodriguez Jr wins.

text_headline: 13 ARTISTS AWARDS
text_description: The First CCP Thirteen Artists Award is given to Raymundo Albano, Angelito Antonio (b. 1939), Virgilio Aviado (b. 1944), Eduardo Castrillo (1942-2016), Benedicto Cabrera, Restituto Embuscado, Marciano Galang (b. 1945), Lamberto Hechanova (1939-2014), Jaime de Guzman, Noel Manalo, Ben Maramag (b. 1945), Manuel Rodriguez Jr, and Antonio Austria (b. 1936).

The exhibit Illumination at the CCP is considered the first sound art exhibit in a gallery setting, organized by the collaborative group Liwayway Recapping Co., composed of Roberto Chabet, Ray Albano, and Boy Perez.
The Nagkakaisang Progresibong Artista-Arkitekto (NPAA) is founded, advocating the tenets of social realism and protest art.

Protest art develops during the martial law period in the form of comics, murals, posters, drawings and illustrations for books, papier-mâché effigies, prints in etching, aquatint or rubbercut, photography, peryodikits (instant posters pasted on walls), masks, t-shirt printing, and even pendants and greeting cards as vehicles for political messages.

Artist-run spaces serve as alternative venues of art practice, such as Gallery 7, Sanctuary, Gallery Indigo, the short-lived Shop 6 in Cubao, and one of the stalls of the Kamalig arcade in Manila, where artists experiment with various materials and provide critical views on the political situation of the country.
A growing impulse to mount shows away from institutional centers manifests in both protest art done in situ or on the streets and communities.

media_caption: Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Mga Ninuno VIII, 1979
media_credit: (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)
text_description: Imelda Cajipe-Endaya (b. 1949) starts the Mga Ninuno series, 1976-1979. The prints explore images from The Boxer Codex, 19th-century engravings and novenas, and Damian Domingo's albums, as commentary on Philippine society.
The Metropolitan Museum of Manila is founded to serve as exhibition venue for international art, while the Museum of Philippine Art is founded to show local work.
Kulay-Anyo ng Lahi mural project is launched in Metro Manila by the government as part of its beautification campaign to boost tourism.

Kaisahan is formed, an art collective employing social realism with members Pablo ‘Adi’ Baens Santos (b. 1943), Edgar Talusan Fernandez (b. 1955), Renato Habulan (b. 1953), Antipas ‘Biboy’ Delotavo (b. 1954), Papo de Asis, Albert Jimenez, and Jose Cuaresma. They are later joined by Al Manrique, Neil Doloricon (b. 1957), Jose Tence Ruiz (b. 1956), Orlando Castillo (b. 1947), Charles Funk, and Vin Toledo.

Pamilya Pintura, a regional art group based in Bacolod, is formed. Its members include Nunelucio Alvarado (b. 1950), Charlie Co (b. 1960), Perry Argel, Jojo Regollo, Danny Dojillo, Norberto “Peewee” Roldan (b. 1953), Norberto Tarroja, Dennis Ascalon, Diokno Pasilan (b. 1963), and Boy Garovillo.
The Central Bank publishes one volume of its Kayamanan series on its painting collection, written by Emmanuel Torres.

People and Art of the Philippines is published in connection with an exhibit held at the Museum of Cultural History of the University of California in Los Angeles, with text by Gabriel Casal OSB, Regalado Trota Jose, and others.
Leonidas Benesa’s (1928-1984) Okir is published, focusing on printmaking and its link with indigenous wood carving.
Alice Guillermo (1938- 2018) writes Social Realism in the Philippines.
The first Fete dela Wsk exhibit sound art is held.
Cesar Legaspi receives the National Artist award.

The First Metrobank Annual Painting Competition opens. The winners in the mixed media category from 1984 to 1987 are Dindo Peralta, Raymon Maliwat, Alwin Reamillo, Nelson E. Ferraris, Noel El Farol, Manuel K. Tan, Gabriel Barredo, Angelito L. Lopez, Arnaldo B. Mirasol, Joel Marayag Ferrer, and Roberto Feleo.
Pinaglabanan Galleries (1984-1989), where artists and curators produce experimental art shows, opens in San Juan.

Artist-run space and collective Surrounded By Water (SBW) is established by Wire Tuazon (b. 1973) and includes members Mike Adrao, Victor Balanon, Argie Bandoy, Jonathan Ching, Mariano Ching, Lena Cobangbang, Louie Cordero, Christina Dy, Lyra Garcellano, Nona Garcia, Geraldine Javier, Keiye Miranda, Mike Muñoz, Jayson Oliviera, Gary Ross Pastrana, Lakay Ranjo, Eric Roca, Amiel Roldan, Erik Sausa, Yasmin Sison, Kreskin Sugay, Ferdz Valencia, and Alvin Villaruel.

Lani Maestro (b. 1957) is awarded the Biennale Prize at the second Havana Biennale for The Dark Depths, an installation consisting of electrical cables, broken glass, and black tar paper with written comments on torture victims.

The Black Artists of Asia (BAA) is organized in Bacolod by artists Nune Alvarado, Peewee Roldan, Charlie Co, Dennis Ascalon, and Lourdes Villanueva. The BAA will later spearhead the Visayan Island Visual Art Exhibition and Conference (VIVA ExCon) in 1990 together with the CCP.

Emmanuel Gutierrez paints the mural Fight for the People’s Right to Know, Fight for Press Freedom in homage to the martyrs who fought the Marcos dictatorship: Macli-ing Dulag, Dr Bobby de la Paz, Edgar Jopson, Dr Johnny Escandor, and Ninoy Aquino. Gutierrez himself is later killed in a military encounter.
The Lakaran project of Rene Aquitania (b. 1961) starts from Manila to Baguio, with the artist picking and collecting objects along his path.
The exhibit Piglas, which features protest art, is shown at the CCP signaling a broadened artistic direction.

The Kababaihan sa Sining at Bagong Sibol na Kamalayan (Kasibulan), a feminist art organization is founded by visual artists Brenda Fajardo (b. 1940), Imelda Cajipe Endaya, Anna Fer (b. 1941), Ida Bugayong, and Julie Lluch (b. 1946).

Brenda Fajardo starts to paint the Baraha ng Buhay Pilipino aka Tarot Card series appropriating the images of the Babaylan (Shaman), Gaga (the Fool), Salamangkero (Magician), among others, to provide social commentary on Philippine society.
The First Baguio Arts Festival is held. It helps to call attention to art from the regions and demonstrates the organizing skills of regional artists embarking on an international event.

First VIVA ExCon is held in Bacolod, led by Peewee Trinidad, Charlie Co, and Nune Alvarado, among others. In coordination with the CCP, it aims to formulate Visayan aesthetics from the different islands.
Traditional woodcarvers in Pampanga are affected by dislocation after the eruption and the long-term effect of the lahar flow. Contemporary potters experiment in creating pottery using lahar.
From Anito to Assemblage is written by Alice Guillermo and others, in conjunction with a retrospective of Philippine painting and sculpture at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila.
The National Museum publishes Faces from Maitum: The Archaeological Excavation of Ayub Cave, authored by Eusebio Dizon and Rey Santiago and edited by Esperanza Bunag Gatbonton.

Discovering Philippine Art in Spain is published to commemorate the centennial celebration of the proclamation of Philippine Independence. The book includes a discussion on ethnological art, Muslim military art, Christian art, and secular art, written by Jose Maria Cariño, Felice Sta. Maria (b. 1950), Brenda Fajardo, Abraham Sakili, Regalado Trota Jose, and Santiago Pilar.

Nona Garcia (b. 1978) wins the Grand Prize in the Philip Morris Group of Companies ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) Art Awards in Singapore and the Juror's Choice distinction in the Philip Morris Philippine Art Awards for the painting See Saw.
Tupada Action and Media Art (TAMA) or TUPADA is founded, composed of young artists interested in performance art in public spaces.
Flaudette May Datuin (b. 1960) writes Home Body Memory: Filipina Artists in the Visual Arts, 19th Century to the Present.

media_caption: Alfredo Esquillo Jr, MamaKinley, 2003
media_credit: (Photo from the artist)
text_description: Alfredo Esquillo (b. 1972) paints Mamakinley as a critique of Philippine-USA relations and is lauded at the Whitney Museum of American Art’s 2003 exhibition The American Effect: Global Perspectives on the United States 1990-2003.

Abraham Sakili’s Space and Identity: Expressions in the Culture, Art and Society of the Muslims in the Philippines is published, exploring the contribution of Islamic belief and Southeast Asian links to the traditional art of the Muslim Filipino.
The first Ateneo Art Awards competition is launched. The first awardees are Louie Cordero (1978), Geraldine Javier (1970), and Jayson Oliveria (1973).
The GAMABA is awarded to Darhata Sawabi (1957-2005) for Tausug pis syabit weaving, Haja Amina Appi (1925-2013) for Sama mat weaving, and Eduardo Mutuc (b. 1949) for silversmithing or pukpuk.
Ginto: History Wrought in Gold by Ramon Villegas (1953-2017) is published based on the collection of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas.
The Constantino Foundation commissions the Tutok artist collective to create two murals that commemorate the heroism of Macario Sakay and Lean Alejandro.

media_caption: Manuggul jar
text_headline: The Manunggul Jar (890-710 BCE), an earthenware pottery found in Palawan in the 1960s and featuring human figures rowing a boat, is used as a secondary burial jar.
text_description: The Manunggul Jar (890-710 BCE), an earthenware pottery found in Palawan in the 1960s and featuring human figures rowing a boat, is used as a secondary burial jar.

media_caption: Project M201: In God We Trust, Alfredo Juan, Isabel Aquilizan, 2003
media_credit: (Photo from The Drawing Room)
text_description: Project M201: In God We Trust by Alfredo Juan (b. 1962) and Isabel Aquilizan (b. 1965) is exhibited as part of the 50th Venice Biennale, which offers a rethinking of the jeepney as representation of Filipino culture.
Daguerre-type photography is officially accepted by the French government on Jan 7, 1839 and introduced to the Philippines in the 1840s.

media_caption: Julie Lluch, Thinking Nude
media_credit: (Photo from Singapore National Heritage Board)
text_description: Thinking Nude, a terra-cotta sculpture by Julie Lluch, explores a feminist trajectory in her art practice.

media_caption: Our Lady of Peace and Good Voyage, NUESTRA SEÑORA DE LA  PAZ Y BUEN VIAJE  Aka Birhen ng Antipolo, early 17th
media_credit: (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)
text_headline: The image of the Virgin Mary called Nuestra Señora de la Paz y Buenviaje, popularly known as Birhen ng Antipolo, is brought by Gov Gen Juan Niño de Taborato to the Philippines in 1626 from a parish in Acapulco.
text_description: The image of the Virgin Mary called Nuestra Señora de la Paz y Buenviaje, popularly known as Birhen ng Antipolo, is brought by Gov Gen Juan Niño de Taborato to the Philippines in 1626 from a parish in Acapulco.

media_caption: Ivory Crucified Christ, 16th-17th century, largest and finest ivory crucifix
text_headline: Religious art forms are crafted for the Catholic church, for the purpose of conversion of the native population. Chinese artisans are conscripted to create paintings, engravings, sculptures, vestments, furniture, and church decorations.
text_description: Religious art forms are crafted for the Catholic church, for the purpose of conversion of the native population. Chinese artisans are conscripted to create paintings, engravings, sculptures, vestments, furniture, and church decorations.

media_caption: Palm leaf woven into bituon (star)
media_credit: (Photos from Palaspas: An Appreciation of Palm Leaf Art in the Philippines by Elmer I. Nocheseda. Ateneo de Manila University Press, 2009.)
text_description: Elmer Nocheseda’s Palaspas is published.
